title: Do you know anyone who does not like philosophy? And why do they not like philosophy? - Quora

response.answer_text: Yes. I know a plenty of people who don’t like philosophy, though also without disliking it. People in general don’t dislike philosophy, even though they also don’t like it: they simply don’t care. The fact that talking about philosophy e.g. in a cocktail party is disliked hasn’t got much to do with philosophy per se — it’s merely because you’re supposed to talk about light subjects, which are easy to approach. In this sense it depends on when, where, to whom, how much, in what way, etc. but I’ll concentrate on professional philosophy.  The reason why most people today don’t specifically like or dislike professional philosophy is, that it’s like pure mathematics or such things, which are interesting only for the people who are highly specialized in that area of knowledge. Mostly people who specifically dislike philosophy, are either   a.) professional philosophers, or  b.) entertain highly naive metaphysical beliefs.The first group dislikes philosophy because they’re so good at it: it’s for them an actual profession, i.e. their thinking is on a level that takes the fun out of it.The latter group dislikes philosophy because they’re so bad at it: thinking the “big questions” is a fun hobby, so they can pretend to be “profound”, i.e. they get annoyed when confronted by actual philosophy.   Then again, quite a few people in general do entertain highly naive metaphysical beliefs about a lot of things and get annoyed when confronted by philosophy — but they probably do that every time their opinions are questioned and criticized, regardless of the topic.   In current everyday understanding there is more bias against some sciences than others, e.g. humanistic sciences like philology are generally thought to have no rules whatsoever, i.e. knowledge about ancient languages is thought to be without value for understanding ancient cultures through their literary remains. This is probably because people in general have a strong tendency to instinctually simplify reality — the reality of different kinds of sciences and areas of knowledge contradicts their intuition, which can feel uncomfortable.  People outside philosophy much more often have biased views about philosophy than e.g. nuclear physics. This is partly because the subject matter is different, i.e. nuclear physics is so outside everyday understanding, that non-professionals usually understand they don’t understand it. Philosophy on the other hand has a much more closer relationship with everyday understanding: while the “matter” of nuclear physics is nature outside man, the “matter” of philosophy is nature inside man.   Philosophy is closer to the world of man and people are inclined to think they always have a better understanding about the things which are nearer — even though the problem with philosophy is like looking for your eyeglasses when you’re wearing them: the problem area of philosophy is so close that people mostly aren’t conscious about it. When someone’s naive metaphysics are confronted by actual philosophy, they’ll accept it more grudgingly, since it’s for them more difficult to understand, that they’re not advanced thinkers on that topic.

Kierkegaard wrote “Philosophical Crumbs” in 1844 when he was aged 31. He wrote in the preface, that any philosophy student could understand his book on reading it, but he doubted that they could reproduce it from memory. I wonder if this means that they didn't really understand it? Or does it mean that understanding is temporary and fleeting? I find myself in the same situation with most philosophy. I can't for the life of me remember what this or that philosopher said. And in fact I can't even begin to understand a lot of it. So I have to confess that I “don't like” philosophy, but I feel a sympathy with a limited number of philosophers. Maybe this is because I am a dilettante rather than a serious student.

I know many people. Many people don’t like to think, and have this unthinking thinking: this is how authoritarian and totalitarian regimes can come and infect societies. Many people accept and do not question. Indeed philosophers John Gray and Alexander Herzen believed/ believes that humans do not actually want freedom at all but prefer the comfort of servitude. Indeed most philosophy, according to John N. Gray, has been a shame because it has unthinkingly been infected with religious thinking and faith instead of grounded reality and truth.

Hawking vs Philosophy | Full Debate | Lewis Wolpert, Steve Fuller, Jonathon Derbyshire Andie, Philosophy invents meaning, in the sense that it can be used to create new meaning in language. To compare philosophy to science is a strawman argument. The value of philosophy is not the discovery of new facts about the universe it is describing the universe in ways that humanity can understand and think about. Some scientist particularly in the above youtube link, seem to want all of us to think like scientists, to work as a scientist but I don’t know what living like a scientist would look like. I can not live my life scientifically, but I can live it rationally and I can desire to become a little wiser from day today. I do not see becoming a little more scientific day to day as being practical or leading to a meaningful life. I am not saying that science is unimportant in our day to day lives, it touches upon almost everything we think, feel, and do… and we have to give unto science what is sciences, but scientism is not the only worldview.

There is none. Yet, your apprehension could be right. Because, they don’t like the “definition of philosophy” you propose or happen to have. If you any time connect philosophy to a shred of pedagogy or an intellectual specialization, the problem begins to brew. Can we make philosophy as simple as “essential personal wisdom” arising out of “selective collection and conscious integration of emotive experiences”? By this, we would have also modified the definition of “wise knowledge” to make it “most emotive”, and “least academic”. Acknowledging the fact that a common man may be endowed with more “essential knowledge” than most academicians or the most recognized academician could be the new beginning of the process of universal philosophizing of mankind. What the public has been resenting all these years is “incarceration of philosophy in the academic campus” which could be seen as its being hijacked by the “non-emotive intellect-simulating professionalism”.

I know many who do not like PHILOSOPHERS… but when you just mention a common philosophical principle (preferably without using the TERMINOLOGY of Philosophy)… the philosophical discussion and debate flows QUITE freely! Just try saying, at a bar or party… that you wish the political parties would just be banned and done with! The discussion, debate, and diatribe will be VERY philosophical, very natural, and VERY intense! But say that you’re interested in discussing political philosophy … people’s eyes will roll, and the melodramatic sighs of exasperated boredom will be emitted from all four corners of the room. That’s all because the term Philosophy has been severely (possibly UNALTERABLY) linked with the Philosophical Equivalent of Medical Quackery. What the Bleep Do We Know!? - Wikipedia

Yes, I was one of those people until I read my first philosophy book about 30 years ago. I’ve been hooked ever since. I’ve read just about every famous book of philosophy since then. I am a retired professional engineer with 40 years of experience. And, yet, I have not found any kind of knowledge that ranks higher than philosophy. Don’t knock it unless you’ve tried it. It will exercise those little gray cells in your head for you — and, you’ll be much better off as a consequence.

Yes, I know some scientists and engineers who don’t like philosophy because 1) they don’t understand it, and are not willing to study it, and 2) they have a misguided belief that philosophy is somehow in competition with science, which it isn’t.

Philosophy is the most respected word in Europe. Of course likers with dislikers and indifferents agree. What 100% always agree is “my philosophy” when anybody says that, you see how deep respect has. For himself. Try it!
Most people I know don’t like philosophy, because it is difficult and inconclusive, and consequently they wrongly suspect that it is BS.
Yes. Often due to a misconception on its lack of relevance or literally on what it even is.
